App description:
***Winner Tribeca Film Festival  Storyscapes Award *** 
** Winner Grand Jury Prize for Best VR Venice Film Festival**
*Narrated by Alia Shawkat*

Meet Anna. Anna doesnt remember her past, but she has vivid dreams about it. In every one of her dreams, there is a mysterious Key. Will you be able to unlock the mystery behind The Key without sacrificing too much?

The Key is a magical realism experience that will take you on a journey through dreams, facing challenges and difficult decisions, leading to a shocking reveal. The Key is NOT a video game. So relax, and let the story guide you.

(20-minute, standing interactive theatrical VR experience) 

10' x 10' play area recommended - Touch things to interact - hold the trigger to teleport

One of Tribeca's breakout successes - CNET

Of particular note are the superbly executed virtual reality technical details, including character design, use of color, and sound design.
Jury - Tribeca Film Festival
Purchase section: FreeAdd to WishlistShareComfortableSupports QuestSupports Oculus TouchInternet connection not required

StephenGdBaker19 days ago
Interesting

For all the complainers, it LITERALLY says documentary on the title page. It was intriguing. I didn't find it so sad but maybe because it's not new info for me. It was very well done and visually interesting. I'm going to have to ask someone about their keys.

Helpful | 13

Alex994May 30 at 5:06 PM
This Experience left me in Tears !!

I was so curious to find out about the story of this key, and then when I reached the end I couldn't hold my tears ...
I am a Syrian refugee, and I still have my home key, even though I know I will never be able to go back
when I finished it I cried so much , I had no clue that this experience would be that much related to me, during the whole experience I was trying to do something but I wasn't able to , I didn't have a choice , just like in real life , I couldn't save my friends , I couldn't stay home , I had to leave , but I survived .
this is the best experience I've had in VR and even though I cried a lot , it really made me happy to know that there are people who know how I feel , know the struggle I've been through , know the story of the Key.

Helpful | 168

tempistraven5 days ago
Liked it, but too preachy at the end

I would of given it a 3.5 If the system allowed it. I love the graphics and the slow mechanics through the game as you look at how memories are seen through someone trying to remember. The end unfortunately was too slow with dramatic pauses that did not show how to trigger the next line or if the lines where meant to be that way. Could not wait and killed it before all the facts where done.

Helpful | 1

TailgunJul 11 at 12:29 PM
Just an Empty Polemic on Refugees

What's meant to be a moving VR story is really nothing more than a bait-and-switch, manipulative, preachy polemic on refugees and how it's our First World responsibility to house all of them (because of course, it is). Save yourself the storage space on your Quest, there are many better experiences, like Notes on Blindness and the Anne Frank House.

Unplayable for me :( wheelchair user

I can't play it as I'm paraplegic and can't stand up.. Please devs can you add a seated mode with smooth or step turning to make it accessible for all, thanks

Helpful | 119
Developer ResponseApr 22 at 11:17 AM

Hi there. I'm the creator of The Key and I take your feedback very seriously. I apologize for not delivering an experience that works for everyone... In the Rift version of the app, we have implemented a "snap turn" to make it compatible with seated mode. We received feedbacks from Quest users that this was making them disoriented so we removed it from the Quest version of the app. Please know that Oculus specifically requested the seated mode for Rift and they are very concerned about making as many experiences as possible available to everyone. This is 100% on me and I hope you'll accept my apology.

Chris.Becca11Apr 16 at 5:30 PM
Love love love

This game is awesome.. I love it, I cried so much. I try to contain it but it was really hard. This is the most saddest VR game I have ever experience. But in a good way. It awesome to learn what we don't know about what going on , in other countries. It really sad that this countries have to go thru this kind of stuff. We all need to take the time to pray for these countries that don't have a say so or a voice to be heard. We take to much for granted and don't realize how good we have it in the United States. This VR game is my favorite out of all the VR games out there.. Thank you for sharing your experience with everyone around the world.. we need to see more of these types of games. Please everyone take the time to place this game. I promise you will not be disappointed.. And you have to pay attention to the narrator to experience what this woman went thru just like if it was you.

A Unique, Eye-Opening Experience

Just a commercial of how refugees suffer

(SPOILERS)

This is just propaganda meant to make you feel bad for refugees. It goes into a speech about the estimated number of refugees that suffer and have to leave their homes as you, the captive audience stand there in a blown up building. Its just a political and ideological messages and speech thinly wrapped in a couple of pretty images. At first, you think its a visual experience and that its a mystery. Then it just transports you into a place and tells you how many refugees have to leave their homes and lose loved ones and how they have to suffer though an agonizing wait before they can be let into the United States and provided food and shelter here. I came here from another country and I dont want anyone talking about me like Im some poor victim. Most refugees dont want to be seen as victims. An important experience.

It also makes a strong point about empathy and caring for those that are less fortunate.

Stays with you

This experience / interactive movie is a simple, short piece with an important message. The life of the protagonist gets progressively worse and unfair as the story goes on, and I found myself wondering why it was happening, and why it was so unfair that whatever happened happened.
